about.summary: An implementation of z-curves - a method for estimating expected discovery and replicability rates on the bases of test-statistics of published studies. The package provides functions for fitting the new density and EM version (Bartoš & Schimmack, 2020, <doi:10.31234/osf.io/urgtn>), censored observations, as well as the original density z-curve (Brunner & Schimmack, 2020, <doi:10.15626/MP.2018.874>). Furthermore, the package provides summarizing and plotting functions for the fitted z-curve objects. See the aforementioned articles for more information about the z-curves, expected discovery and replicability rates, validation studies, and limitations.

name: r-zcurve

about.summary: An implementation of z-curves - a method for estimating expected discovery and replicability rates on the bases of test-statistics of published studies. The package provides functions for fitting the new density and EM version (Bartoš & Schimmack, 2020, <doi:10.31234/osf.io/urgtn>), censored observations, as well as the original density z-curve (Brunner & Schimmack, 2020, <doi:10.15626/MP.2018.874>). Furthermore, the package provides summarizing and plotting functions for the fitted z-curve objects. See the aforementioned articles for more information about the z-curves, expected discovery and replicability rates, validation studies, and limitations.

raw_meta_yaml:
{% set version = '2.1.2' %}

{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}
{% set native = 'm2w64-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-zcurve
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/zcurve_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/zcurve/zcurve_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: 127856eb5489ef1bb77c9d40787383bf2b9cc05e7198000ec67bb58d596caa48

build:
  merge_build_host: True  # [win]
  number: 1
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}  # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_c') }}  # [win]
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}  # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_cxx') }}  # [win]
    - {{ posix }}filesystem  # [win]
    - {{ posix }}make 
    - {{ posix }}sed  # [win]
    - {{ posix }}coreutils  # [win]
    - {{ posix }}zip  # [win]

  host:
    - r-base
    - r-rcpp >=1.0.2
    - r-rdpack
    - r-evmix
    - r-nleqslv

  run:
    - r-base
    - {{ native }}gcc-libs  # [win]
    - r-rcpp >=1.0.2
    - r-rdpack
    - r-evmix
    - r-nleqslv

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('zcurve')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('zcurve')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://fbartos.github.io/zcurve/
  dev_url: https://github.com/FBartos/zcurve
  license: GPL-3.0-only
  summary: "An implementation of z-curves - a method for estimating expected discovery and replicability
    rates on the bases of test-statistics of published studies. The package provides
    functions for fitting the new density and EM version (Barto\u0161 & Schimmack, 2020,
    <doi:10.31234/osf.io/urgtn>), censored observations, as well as the original density
    z-curve (Brunner & Schimmack, 2020, <doi:10.15626/MP.2018.874>). Furthermore, the
    package provides summarizing and plotting functions for the fitted z-curve objects.
    See the aforementioned articles for more information about the z-curves, expected
    discovery and replicability rates, validation studies, and limitations."
  license_file:
    - '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/GPL-3'

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r
    - thewchan

# The original CRAN metadata for this package was:

# Maintainer: Frantisek Bartos <f.bartos96@gmail.com>
# Description: An implementation of z-curves - a method for estimating expected discovery and replicability rates on the bases of test-statistics of published studies. The package provides functions for fitting the new density and EM version (Bartos & Schimmack, 2020, <doi:10.31234/osf.io/urgtn>), censored observations, as well as the original density z-curve (Brunner & Schimmack, 2020, <doi:10.15626/MP.2018.874>). Furthermore, the package provides summarizing and plotting functions for the fitted z-curve objects. See the aforementioned articles for more information about the z-curves, expected discovery and replicability rates, validation studies, and limitations.
